Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2009 07:40AM Lisa_S wrote: I totally understand and was also very concerned to read this.  I'm currently 50 pounds overweight (officially obese).  My weight has fluctuated over the years and I'm really starting to think that I brought the cancer on myself based on this news.  Three years ago I had lost most of the weight and was only 10 pounds overweight, but stress and age have prompted me to change my eating and exercise habits (my excuse, of course) and here I am, 40 pounds more than I was three years ago.  Now I'm worried that I'm going to go through treatment and it won't make a difference.  Clearly I am planning to lose weight, but will it already be too late?  I haven't had chemo yet, but I certainly can't lose weight before my chemo starts (after my second lumpectomy in a couple of weeks).  I've heard that it's more likely that I'll gain rather than lose during this time.  And my radiation oncologist told me that I should not be losing weight during my radiation treatments because it could alter the treatment since they do a calibration in the beginning.  So I guess the only thing I can do is try my best to lose weight when I can -- maybe after my treatment.
